question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings and alleged inaction by police in a land grabbing case. under Section 482 CrPC: The High Court has inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an advocate, has filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings against him and complaining about alleged police inaction in a land grabbing case. The petition lists numerous respondents including the State, police officers, and individuals allegedly involved in land grabbing.
charge: Quashing of proceedings and alleged inaction by police in a land grabbing case.
law_content: Section 482 CrPC: The High Court has inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The case pertains to a criminal petition filed by an advocate. The provided text indicates the petition is against the State of Telangana and various police officers, along with other respondents, concerning alleged land grabbing and related issues. The nature of the relief sought implies a challenge to proceedings or seeking directions for investigation/action. Further details on the specific order or ruling are truncated.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. In this case, it was used to quash proceedings based on prior High Court orders.?
facts: The petitioners, accused in CC No. 2 of 2018, sought to quash the proceedings initiated against them under the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003. The case was filed before the Judicial First Class Magistrate at Utnoor. The petitioners argued that similar matters had been dealt with by the High Court in previous orders.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. In this case, it was used to quash proceedings based on prior High Court orders.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition, quashing the proceedings against the petitioners in CC No. 2 of 2018, in line with its previous common orders on similar matters. The court also allowed the petitioners to seek return of seized property from the Magistrate.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in C.C.No. 359 of 2018 for an alleged offence under the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - This section empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The specific offence is under Section 20(2) rlw 7(2) of the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003.?

The case was registered for an offence under Section 20(2) read with 7(2) of the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003. The specific offence is under Section 20(2) rlw 7(2) of the Cigarettes and Tobacco Products Act, 2003.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition and quashed the proceedings against the petitioners in C.C.No. 359 of 2018, based on previous common orders passed by the court in similar matters. The petitioners were granted liberty to file an application for the return of seized property, and any expired stock was to be destroyed with the Magistrate's permission.

The case was registered for alleged offences under Sections 270 and 273 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The petitioners had previously approached the High Court in similar cases.

judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition and quashed the proceedings against the petitioners in C.C.No. 472 of 2017, in terms of previous common orders passed by the court in similar matters. question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR No. 235/2023 registered under Section 379 IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The section allows the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer. This section lays down the procedure for issuing a notice of appearance to an accused person in cases where arrest is not required.?
facts: The petitioners, accused in FIR No. 235 of 2023 registered under Section 379 IPC, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings. The alleged offence carries a punishment of less than seven years.
charge: Quashing of FIR No. 235/2023 registered under Section 379 IPC.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The section allows the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer. This section lays down the procedure for issuing a notice of appearance to an accused person in cases where arrest is not required.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer and allowed the Investigating Officer to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar vs. State of Bihar. The petitioners were directed to cooperate with the investigation.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. deal with the provisions for granting bail. The NDPS Act relates to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, with Sections 8(c) and 20(b)(ii)(B) concerning possession and consumption of ganja, and Section 22 relating to punishment for certain offences. Section 34 of IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No.4, was arrested for consumption and possession of 2kgs of ganja, for offences under the NDPS Act and IPC. He is a student with upcoming examinations.
charge: Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C.
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. deal with the provisions for granting bail. The NDPS Act relates to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, with Sections 8(c) and 20(b)(ii)(B) concerning possession and consumption of ganja, and Section 22 relating to punishment for certain offences. Section 34 of IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.
judgment: The High Court granted regular bail to the petitioner, considering he is a student with upcoming exams and has no previous cases. The bail was granted subject to executing a personal bond, furnishing sureties, and appearing before the police station on specified dates and as required.

judgment: The High Court, considering the nature of the offences and the punishment prescribed, directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer and directed the officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petition was disposed of with these directions.
